Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This program will investigate superconductor-insulator transitions (SITs) of ultrathin films of elements and simple compounds. These transitions are the simplest examples of continuous quantum phase transitions, which occur at zero temperature, when the ground state of a system is changed in response to the variation of an external parameter. Quantum phase transitions, which are macroscopic manifestations of quantum mechanics, are studied through measurements of behaviors influenced by quantum fluctuations that persist at low, but nonzero temperatures. Investigations will include a study of the Nernst effect across the magnetic-field-tuned transition, and measurements of the penetration depth in the critical region with the goal of identifying the critical exponent of the order parameter and the universality class. In addition, the electronic compressibility near the critical point, which would be a thermodynamic signature of the SI transition, and the dissipation-tuned-SI-transition will be investigated. Electric double layer transistor configurations will be used to modify the electronic and superconducting properties of FeSe films. The broader impacts include training of graduate students in a traditional physics Ph.D. program and providing a venue for useful and positive research experiences for undergraduates. The work proposed will impact the understanding of known novel superconductors and the search for new ones. The primary outreach activity will be the teaching of freshman seminars by the PI on physics topics.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
This award supports investigations of the superconductor-insulator transitions of elements and simple compounds. Superconductor-insulator transitions are among the simplest quantum phase transitions, and they are especially fundamental because of their connection to the Uncertainty Principle of quantum mechanics. Quantum phase transitions are an important paradigm in contemporary condensed matter science and understanding their nature is an important challenge in part because of their role in high temperature superconductivity. Quantum phase transitions, in contrast with conventional thermodynamic phase transitions, which are controlled by temperature, and occur at nonzero temperature, are transitions, which are controlled by external parameters such as magnetic field, pressure, or charge density, and occur at absolute zero. They have measurable signatures at low, but nonzero temperatures, which will be used to characterize them. The study of superconductor-insulator transitions requires advanced tools of experimental science such as nanofabrication, thin film growth, and ultra-low temperature cryogenic measurement techniques. This project supports the training of both Ph.D. and undergraduate students that is excellent preparation for a scientific career. The primary outreach activity will be the teaching of freshman seminars by the PI on contemporary physics topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on the experimental investigation of superconductor-insulator transitions (SITs) of thin films of elements and compounds. These transitions are examples of an important paradigm of contemporary condensed matter physics, the quantum phase transition (QPT).  QPTs occur at zero temperature, when the ground state of  system is changed in response to the variation of an external parameter. In the case of the SIT, which is one of the simplest QPTs, this could be parallel or perpendicular magnetic field, disorder, or charge density. QPTs are studied through the measurement at nonzero temperatures of physical behaviors influenced by quantum fluctuations associated with the QPT, which persist to nonzero temperatures. These fluctuations are distinct from critical thermal fluctuations, which are associated with conventional phase transitions tuned by temperature, such as the ferromagnetic transition. In this project the main focus was on the perpendicular magnetic field-tuned superconductor-insulator transitions of films of indium oxide and ultra-thin films of amorphous bismuth.

In part of the work on indium oxide, we employed two tuning parameters, charge density and magnetic field, and we studied films which had different levels of intrinsic disorder.  We were able to traverse the superconductor-insulator transition in zero magnetic field by adding electrons to the films through electrostatic gating using an ionic liquid as the dielectric in an electric double layer transistor configuration. This device facilitates the transfer of much more charge to the film than is possible using a conventional field effect transistor configuration with a high dielectric constant gate insulator. We investigated how varying  the charge density affected the magnetic field-tuned superconductor-insulator transition. This approach enabled us to induce, and then continuously change the size and the position of the large magnetoresistance peak that is found in the high-field insulating regime. Our findings shed light on the origin of this peak and the possibility of localized superconducting islands within the insulating regime.

In work on the SIT of ultrathin films of bismuth, we correlated the appearance of the large magnetoresistance peak with an analysis of film roughness which highlighted the role of mesoscopic scale thickness fluctuations in nucleating superconducting islands, which lead to the magnetoresistance peak. This work, together with the electrostatic gating experiment described above, highlights the delicate interplay of charge carrier density with disorder in determining the character of the insulating state with its iconic magnetoresistance peak.

We then turned to a study of the superconducting side of the magnetic field-tuned superconductor-insulator transition of indium oxide films. The issue was the mechanism for the electrical resistance found at nonzero temperatures near the critical magnetic field, a matter that had largely been ignored. Electrical resistance in superconductors is usually attributed to the creep and flow vortices. As a result of careful measurements of the temperature dependence of the resistance in various magnetic fields we concluded that the resistance is due to two-dimensional hopping of vortices obeying the vortex analog of Mott variable-range hopping.

During a move to a new laboratory building, when our dilution refrigerators were temporarily unavailable, we carried out simpler experiments which depended on equipment that could be quickly set up. We searched for superconductivity in silicon wafers by electrostatic doping of carriers using ionic liquids in an electric double layer transistor configuration. Superconductivity had been reported in chemically-doped silicon. We did not find superconductivity, but instead discovered a unique insulator-to-metal transition in the two-dimensional hole gas induced on the surface of low mobility silicon wafers. The critical sheet carrier density was higher than any previously reported. We also observed a peak in the mobility as a function of carrier density.  In addition, by analyzing hopping conduction in less heavily doped wafers, we clarified the physics of the gating of solids by ionic liquids.

The research performed with support from this project involved three graduate students, who received doctoral degrees. The major broader impact of the project was in the training of these students for the scientific work force. The student who worked on electrostatic gating of indium oxide is a postdoc at Lawrence -Berkeley Laboratory in the materials area.  The student who worked on the electrostatic gating of silicon is now a scientist working on quantum computing at the University of Rochester.  The student who worked on variable-range hopping of vortices is continuing her research at the University of Minnesota, but eventually intends to work in high-technology industry in the Twin Cities area.

The project also impacts the broader field of condensend matter science. The investigation of the simplest of QPTs can lead to a deeper understanding of the QPTs of more complex materials, which are the focus of much research on quantum materials. Although we did not find superconductivity in silicon by electrostatic doping with ionic liquids, the technique is  a promising way to search for new  superconductors.
